attributes.body:
Sweet Flight, At Last

As long as I can remember I've wanted to fly. It's a recurring dream, in sleep, and in waking life. And I finally got to do it.

Meet Willie

Claudia and Carlos were awesome enough to bring me to their favorite paragliding instructor. We showed up early, and didn't really know if Willie would be there. Eventually he came. Claudia told him I was investigating taking a course, and he immediately waved me over, and slapped me into a harness. Before we had spoken three sentences he had me with my hands on the controls, and was telling me to lean my body more into the turn.

No questions, no contracts, no liability waivers. There's something great about that.

Paragliding School

Things go pretty quick. I flew solo after just about five days of class, and felt pretty confident in doing so. Usually lessons would include some time working on ground handling, and some tandem flight time to practice take offs, turns, and landings.

One day, Willie turned to me and asked how ready I felt on a scale of 1 to 10. I told him about a five, thinking about how much work I wanted to do on ground handling. And he told me he thought I was closer to a 7. Flying, and ground handling are sort of two separate things, of course, you can get yourself into trouble with either in the wrong conditions.

photos.title: Radio Controlled Glider
photos.description: This thing was too fast to photograph in the air.

photos.title: Thermals and Clouds
photos.description: This guy seemed to find a nice thermal.

photos.title: Catching Glider
photos.description: They had a game of trying to catch the gliders as they came around. Nobody even got hurt.

photos.title: Clouds and Sunset
photos.description: You can see some of the rainclouds off to the right. They kept zipping by with all of the wind, and people would seek shelter, then run back out and fly more.

photos.title: Sunset
photos.description: I took a photo of the sunset, but I wasn't happy with it. It didn't really say anything about what was happening. I stepped back a bit, and took this photo. This is the place where everyone sits and watches the paragliders. Also, where they seek shelter. And where some women sell beers, sodas, and snacks on the weekends.

photos.title: Paragliding Take Off
photos.description: This is where you take off. In this photo is Edgar's brother, Carlos with my instructor Willie. Once you get the wing up, you take a few steps forward, and away you go.

photos.title: Willie Teaching Paragliding
photos.description: Willie is here with me. He's my instructor for paragliding. His english isn't perfect, but neither is my spanish. We work it out, he's patient with me, and is sure to stress things that could result in injury.

photos.title: Paraglider Ground Handling
photos.description: This is one of my earlier lessons in which Willie is helping me figure out the ground handling thing. As it turns out, this is one of the most challenging aspects of paragliding.

photos.title: Tangled Paraglider Cords
photos.description: Tangles happen surprisingly little, but when they do...

photos.title: Cory Ready For First Flight
photos.description: This is me, just getting ready for my first ever solo flight. I'm psyched, and suddenly things are getting real. Don't worry, the helmet is not taped together. Willie rigged up a radio so he could give me instruction from the ground.

photos.title: Cory Paragliding
photos.description: Here I am, up in the air.

photos.title: Paragliding Sunset
photos.description: Here's me flying too close to the sun. Fortunately, my wing didn't melt, and I couldn't imagine a better place to watch the sunset.

photos.title: Time to Land
photos.description: Turning around and coming back in for landing for the day.
